notes: Free/Paid/Enterprise tiers exist.
Paid tier supports higher rate limits, context caching, and Batch API with advertised 50% cost reduction.
Token pricing varies by model and can change. Store/display the provider's official pricing table when available.
This catalog includes the official tier and feature notes, and the Gemini-TTS token pricing separately under google_gemini_tts and google_cloud_tts.
Prompt caching can reduce cost for repeated prompts.
Batch processing is available for asynchronous workloads.
Official product page states pricing starts at these rates; exact pricing may vary by features (prompt caching, batch) and platform.
Prices are per 1,000,000 tokens unless stated otherwise.
Output tokens are typically more expensive than input tokens.
Supports token-billed text/chat models as well as speech-to-text and text-to-speech.
Cached input tokens (when supported) can significantly reduce costs when re-sending the same context.
OpenAI pricing pages were not retrievable from this environment (Forbidden), so these figures were added from user-provided pricing output.

Prices are per 1,000,000 tokens unless stated otherwise.
Cached input tokens are listed as a discounted rate when applicable.
Speech-to-text is priced per audio minute (not tokens) in the user-provided pricing.
Text-to-speech is priced per character in the user-provided pricing.

source_notes: User pasted pricing labeled as 'latest official OpenAI API pricing (as of December 2025)'.

notes: Supports multiple voice types (Standard, WaveNet, Neural2, Studio, Chirp).
Common controls: speaking rate, pitch, audio encoding, language/voice selection.
Character count includes spaces/newlines; SSML tags are generally included in character count (per official pricing notes).
Voice type availability varies by language/region.
Token-priced TTS models; audio tokens correspond to 25 tokens per second of audio (per official pricing).
Designed for controllable speech generation via prompting.
Audio tokens correspond to 25 tokens per second of audio.
Supports Standard, Neural, Generative, and Long-Form voice engines.
Supports SSML and speech marks.
TTS is credits-based; credit usage depends on model.
STT pricing is published per subscription tier with included hours and additional-hour rates.
Free tier requires attribution and does not have commercial licensing (per pricing note).
Subscription tier prices/credits and approximate included TTS minutes were provided by the user.
STT additional-hour examples were sourced from ElevenLabs docs content previously retrieved in this environment.
Verify against ElevenLabs pricing pages before making production billing decisions.

credit_notes: One credit typically equals one character of TTS, but usage can vary by model/quality settings.
Speech-to-text and Agents usage can also consume credits, typically based on duration.

notes: Custom pricing; contact ElevenLabs sales.
Pricing and credit amounts may vary by region and billing cycle (monthly vs annual).
Credit rollover may apply depending on plan terms.
Usage-based billing may be available on some tiers for purchasing extra credits.

tts_notes: This catalog includes user-provided monthly tier prices/credits and approximate included TTS minutes.

If you want a deterministic USD-per-1K-credits estimate for budgeting, compute it from tier price divided by included credits (note: this ignores seats, non-TTS usage, rollovers, and model-dependent credit burn).

notes: Pricing page advertises $200 free credit then pay-as-you-go.
Provides STT, TTS, and voice agent offerings; concurrency limits vary by plan.
This catalog does not include specific per-minute/per-character rates because they are not presented in a machine-readable way on the public pricing page content we retrieved.
If you want hard numbers shown in the UI, we should add them manually after confirming the exact SKUs you plan to use.

rules_of_thumb: For lowest latency interactive play, prefer models/providers with realtime audio or streaming support.
For best reasoning and fewer loopholes, prefer stronger reasoning models even if slightly slower.
Use batch/async modes when generating non-interactive content (backstory generation, summaries, etc.).
Character-priced engines are predictable for budget planning; token-priced engines can be better for expressive/steerable speech.
If you need consistent character voices, choose a provider with strong voice libraries or cloning/remixing tools.
Expose a 'Preview voice' function in the admin UI so configuration is self-serve.
For group play with background noise, prioritize models that perform well on conversational audio and support diarization if needed.
Make language selection explicit (en-US, es-US, etc.) for best accuracy.
